title: Statuette of Venus

thumbnail.alt_text: Profile view of a bronze sculpture with green patina of a nude woman with her right hand raised to eye level. She wears a tiara, her hair in a bun.

description: This statuette depicts Venus, the Roman goddess of love, sexuality, and maternity, with her hair in an elegant updo and wearing nothing but the diadem (crown) atop her head. Earlier images of Venus often represented the goddess modestly clothed, reinforcing her role as exemplary matron and mother of the Roman people. By the first century, Venus was regularly shown fully nude, reflecting body types associated with her Greek counterpart, Aphrodite, whose domain leaned more toward the pleasures of erotic love and seduction. In their respective cultures, both goddesses served as models for brides and matrons: nude forms such as this guided women to cultivate their sexual appeal, thereby fostering the production of children who would carry on society
credit_line: Katherine K. Adler Memorial Endowment Fund; Cynthia and Terry E. Perucca Fund
publication_history:
Katharine A. Raff, "Statuette of Venus", Art Institute of Chicago Blog, published Nov. 17, 2022 (https://www.artic.edu/articles/1018/statuette-of-venus)

M. O. Jentel 1984, LIMC II, Aphrodite (in peripheria orientali), p.159, no. 92.

S. Reinach, Répertoire de la statuaire grecque et romaine, IV, p. 209, no. 6.

A. de Ridder, Collection de Clercq, vol. 3 (Paris: 1905), 65, no. 85, pl. XIII.
provenance_text: Louis de Clercq (1882–1901), Paris [de Ridder 1905, III, no. 85, pl. XIII (no. 3)]; by descent to his grandnephew, Comte Henri de Boisgelin (1901–1967), Paris; Nicolas Koutoulakis (1910–1996), Paris, c. 1967; by descent in the family; private collection, Paris, by 2000. Private collection, 2019; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2022.
department_title: Arts of the Ancient Mediterranean and Byzantium
category_titles: Arts of the Ancient Mediterranean and Byzantium
